articles.headline: For Some Gun Makers, Moving Lock, Stock and Barrel
articles.snippet: After gun laws were strengthened in several states in the wake of the Newtown, Conn., school shooting, some manufacturers are relocating to more gun-friendly states.
articles.abstract: After gun laws were strengthened in several states in the wake of the Newtown, Conn., school shooting, some manufacturers are relocating to more gun-friendly states.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRISTOL, Conn. — Even gun makers want to be liked. So governors and other politicians from states eager to embrace the industry have descended on places where they are not so popular — like Connecticut, Maryland, New York and Colorado — offering tax breaks and outright cash grants to persuade them to relocate.

articles.headline: Qaeda Leader’s Edict to Yemen Affiliate Is Said to Prompt Alert
articles.snippet: American officials said the head of Al Qaeda ordered the leader of the group’s affiliate in Yemen to carry out an attack as early as this past Sunday.
articles.abstract: American officials said the head of Al Qaeda ordered the leader of the group’s affiliate in Yemen to carry out an attack as early as this past Sunday.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Obama administration’s decision last week to close nearly two dozen diplomatic missions and issue a worldwide travel alert came after the United States intercepted electronic communications in which the head of Al Qaeda ordered the leader of the group’s affiliate in Yemen to carry out an attack as early as this past Sunday, according to American officials.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: Bezos, Amazon’s Founder, to Buy The Washington Post
articles.snippet: Jeffrey P. Bezos will pay $250 million for the newspaper and some other businesses of The Washington Post Company.
articles.abstract: Jeffrey P. Bezos will pay $250 million for the newspaper and some other businesses of The Washington Post Company.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Washington Post, the newspaper whose reporting helped topple a president and inspired a generation of journalists, is being sold for $250 million to the founder of Amazon.com, Jeffrey P. Bezos, in a deal that has shocked the industry.

articles.headline: New York Tells Online Lenders to Abide by State’s Interest Rate Cap
articles.snippet: Letters are sent to 35 online lenders for charging more than New York State’s 25 percent interest rate cap.
articles.abstract: Letters are sent to 35 online lenders for charging more than New York State’s 25 percent interest rate cap.
articles.lead_paragraph: Government authorities are homing in on a lucrative loophole that allows online lenders to offer short-term loans at interest rates that often exceed 500 percent annually, the latest front in a crackdown on the payday lending industry.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess

articles.headline: Bankers’ Pay Deferrals Are Tougher in Europe
articles.snippet: Compensation deferral was meant to give employees less incentive to take the kinds of short-term risks that led to the financial crisis.
articles.abstract: Compensation deferral was meant to give employees less incentive to take the kinds of short-term risks that led to the financial crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: Soon after the financial crisis, international regulators identified Wall Street’s lush pay packages as one of the culprits and proposed an overhaul that was meant to apply equally to employees of American investment banks and their big European rivals.

articles.headline: Newspapers Are Billionaires’ Latest Trophies
articles.snippet: Deals to buy The Washington Post and The Boston Globe have been announced this week by very wealthy entrepreneurs.
articles.abstract: Deals to buy The Washington Post and The Boston Globe have been announced this week by very wealthy entrepreneurs.

articles.headline: A Mogul Gets a Landmark in the Capital
articles.snippet: Jeff Bezos, the founder and chief executive of Amazon, has kept a low profile in politics and has said almost nothing about his interest in newspapers, except that he reads them.
articles.abstract: Jeff Bezos, the founder and chief executive of Amazon, has kept a low profile in politics and has said almost nothing about his interest in newspapers, except that he reads them.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — The Washington of Jeffrey P. Bezos has been the one of disruptive technology, fleece jackets and software engineers. He has shown little interest in the Washington of politics, power suits and Woodward and Bernstein.
articles.byline: By Nick Wingfield and David Streitfeld

articles.headline: Chicago Sees Pension Crisis Drawing Near
articles.snippet: Beneath the signs of recovery is one of the most poorly funded pension systems in the nation, threatening to challenge the city’s finances for years to come.
articles.abstract: Beneath the signs of recovery is one of the most poorly funded pension systems in the nation, threatening to challenge the city’s finances for years to come.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Corporations are moving in, and housing prices are looking better across the region. There has been a slight uptick in population. But a crushing problem lurks beneath the signs of economic recovery in Chicago: one of the most poorly funded pension systems among the nation’s major cities. Its plight threatens to upend the finances of President Obama’s hometown, now run by his former chief of staff, Rahm Emanuel.
articles.byline: By Monica Davey and Mary Williams Walsh

articles.headline: Senator Amplifies Her Voice to Referee Fiscal Showdown
articles.snippet: Senator Barbara A. Mikulski, chairwoman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, is charged with heading off what could be the first shutdown of Washington after three years of near misses.
articles.abstract: Senator Barbara A. Mikulski, chairwoman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, is charged with heading off what could be the first shutdown of Washington after three years of near misses.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Seven months into Senator Barbara A. Mikulski’s new assignment as chairwoman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, there is already a saying among members: “We loved Byrd, we respected Inouye, we fear Barbara.”
